dt: {bc}a condition that is characterized especially by physical and mental exhaustion usually with accompanying symptoms (such as headache and irritability), is of unknown cause but is often associated with depression or emotional stress, and is sometimes considered similar to or identical with {d_link|chronic fatigue syndrome|chronic fatigue syndrome}

et: Italian {it}neurastenia{/it} (now {it}nevrastenia{/it}) appears to have been introduced, in reference to what was taken to be a form of tetanus ({it}tetano nervoso{/it} or {it}tetano astenico{/it} "nervous" or "asthenic tetanus"), by the Pavia physician Giuseppe Bergamaschi in "Osservazioni medico-pratiche sul tetano," {it}Giornale di medicina pratica,{/it} edited by Valeriano Luigi Brera, fascicolo 29 (settembre-ottobre 1816). Bergamaschi's {it}neurastenia{/it} is cited as "neurostenia" in John Mason Good's {it}The Study of Medicine,{/it} 2nd edition, vol. 4 (London, 1825), p. 353. The word was reintroduced to refer to a psychological disorder by both the American psychiatrist E.H. Van Deusen ("Observations on a form of nervous prostration, (neurasthenia,) culminating in insanity," {it}American Journal of Insanity,{/it} April, 1869, vol. 45, pp. 445-61) and the American neurologist George Miller Beard ("Neurasthenia, or nervous exhaustion," {it}Boston Medical and Surgical Journal,{/it} new series vol. 3, no. 13, April 29, 1869, pp. 217-21).
shortdef: a condition that is characterized especially by physical and mental exhaustion usually with accompanying symptoms (such as headache and irritability), is of unknown cause but is often associated with depression or emotional stress, and is sometimes considered similar to or identical with chronic fatigue syndrome
